Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2012 07:11PM glasslady062011 wrote: Hello Ladies: I see that some of you are soon to have surgery.  I am 9 months post op - I had a lumpectomy.  Just know that no matter what type of surgery one has to have, we all go through the same process from an emotional and physical standpoint.  You are not alone and you are so far ahead of the game by finding this discussion board.  I didn't even think to look for a discussion forum until about 4 months after surgery. The other thing that helped me was the faith based cancer support group I was already attending with my husband who was diagnosed with colon cancer in 2009.  If you have a support group available in your area, I encourage you to attend as soon as you are well enough to do so. Clothing was another thing I had not prepared well for.  I qualified for focused radiation (mammosite) which required a catheter to be inserted into the area where the tumor was removed.  This catheter stuck out about 8 inches externally.  This meant no regular bra during the 5 days I had the catheter and wearing a bra during the healing process (and the summer time) was not easy some days. So be sure to think about your wardrobe.   For now, I wish you all well in your upcoming procedures.  My prayers will be with you.

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2011 09:36PM glasslady062011 wrote: I just found this site about an hr ago.  Sure could have used it in June when I was going through my recovery.  However, I so related to this topic when I saw it.  Although I had a lumpectomy, I had a balloon cathether inserted 4 days afterwards for 'focused radiation' treatment called mammosite.  This was awesome because I was able to have radiation in 5 days as opposed to 6 weeks.  The downside was the external cathether that you deal with during the time period.  This is much like the drains put in for the mastectomies. After a few days of not being able to get comfortable, I stopped in at a Bed Bath and Beyond after my radiation treatment to pick up a bedrest (the kind with arms).  When placed on top of a plump pillow, you can get fairly comfortable if you need to be in a semi-upright position in bed.  Of course, pillow coming off the armrest areas also help.  Hang in there..  it does get better.
